topic.title: HTML Elements, Tags & Attributes
topic.description: HTML elements are the building blocks of web pages. Each element is created using tags (opening and closing) and can be customized with attributes. Understanding elements, tags, and attributes is essential for creating structured, meaningful HTML documents.

examples.description: HTML elements are either block-level (take full width, start on new line) or inline (flow with text). Understanding this is crucial for layout.

examples.title: Boolean Attributes - Present or Absent
examples.description: Boolean attributes don't need values. Their presence means true, their absence means false. Common in forms and media elements.
examples.code_snippet:
<!-- Form input boolean attributes -->
<input type="text" required>
<!-- required means this field must be filled -->

<input type="checkbox" checked>
<!-- checked means checkbox starts selected -->

<input type="text" disabled>
<!-- disabled means user cannot interact with this field -->

<input type="text" readonly value="Cannot change this">
<!-- readonly means user can see but not edit -->

<input type="email" autofocus>
<!-- autofocus means cursor starts in this field when page loads -->

<!-- Select dropdown boolean attributes -->
<select>
    <option value="1">Option 1</option>
    <option value="2" selected>Option 2</option>
    <option value="3" disabled>Option 3 (cannot select)</option>
</select>

<!-- Media boolean attributes -->
<video src="video.mp4" controls autoplay muted loop></video>
<!-- controls: show play/pause buttons
     autoplay: start playing automatically
     muted: no sound
     loop: replay when finished -->

<!-- Script boolean attribute -->
<script src="app.js" defer></script>
<!-- defer: load script after HTML is parsed -->
examples.output: The required input must be filled before form submission. The checkbox starts checked. The disabled input cannot be clicked. The video plays automatically on muted loop with controls visible. Boolean attributes control behavior through their presence alone.

examples.title: Div and Span - Generic Containers
examples.description: Div (block) and span (inline) are generic containers with no semantic meaning. Use them when no semantic element fits, and add meaningful class names.
examples.code_snippet:
Card Title

Card content goes here.

The price is $29.99 and includes free shipping on orders over $50.

Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
Content

Article Title

Article content

âœ“ Saved successfully!
examples.output: The div creates a card layout with header, body, and footer sections. Span highlights specific words within a paragraph without breaking the text flow. Divs create a grid layout. The semantic example uses article and header which have meaning. The good div example uses clear class names to explain its purpose.

when_to_use.point: Use semantic HTML elements (header, nav, main, article, section, footer) whenever they accurately describe your content structure.
Use div and span only when no semantic element fits the purpose, and always add descriptive class names.
Use global attributes like id, class, and title to make elements identifiable and usable.
Use data attributes to store custom information that JavaScript will need to access.
Use boolean attributes on form inputs and media elements to control behavior.
Use the hidden attribute to hide content rather than using CSS display: none for better semantics.

when_to_avoid.point: Never use div and span everywhere (div soup). Overusing generic containers makes HTML meaningless and harms accessibility.
Avoid using inline style attributes in production. Keep styling in external CSS files for maintainability.
Do not create custom attributes without the data- prefix. Non-standard attributes may conflict with future HTML specifications.
Never use the same id value twice on the same page. IDs must be unique per document.
Avoid putting multiple unrelated purposes in a single class name. Use multiple classes instead.
Do not use presentational class names like 'red-text' or 'big-heading'. Use semantic names like 'error-message' or 'page-title'.

problems.problem: Without proper element choice, content loses semantic meaning. Screen readers and search engines cannot understand page structure if everything is a div.
Without attributes, elements cannot be styled, targeted by JavaScript, or configured with custom behavior.
Before data attributes existed, developers stored data in classes or non-standard attributes, making code fragile and hard to maintain.
Generic containers (div, span) were needed because HTML didn't originally have enough semantic elements. HTML5 added semantic elements to reduce reliance on divs.

mental_models.model: Think of HTML elements like LEGO blocks. Each block type (p, h1, div, img) has a specific shape and purpose. Tags are how you snap the blocks into your structure. Attributes are the custom decorations or labels you stick on each block.
Elements are nouns (things that exist), tags are the syntax that creates those nouns, and attributes are adjectives (properties that describe or modify those things).
Think of div and span like generic boxes and tape in a moving truck. You use them when you need to group or hold things together, but you label the boxes (with class names) so you know what's inside.
Data attributes are like sticky notes on objects. They hold extra information that isn't visible on the surface but that you can read when you need it (especially in JavaScript).

common_mistakes.mistake: Using div for everything instead of semantic elements. This creates 'div soup' where the HTML structure has no meaning, harming accessibility and SEO.
Forgetting to close tags. An unclosed div can break the entire page layout as subsequent elements nest inside it incorrectly.
Using duplicate id values. IDs must be unique per page. If you need to target multiple elements, use classes instead.
Not quoting attribute values. While HTML5 allows unquoted values in some cases, always use quotes for consistency and to avoid bugs.
Creating custom attributes without data- prefix. Attributes like 'user-id' or 'product-name' are invalid. Use 'data-user-id' and 'data-product-name' instead.
Misspelling boolean attributes or adding values to them. Write 'required' not 'required="required"' or 'required="true"'. The presence alone means true.
Using presentational class names like 'blue-button' or 'text-16px' instead of semantic names like 'primary-button' or 'body-text'.
Nesting block elements incorrectly, like putting a div inside a span or a p inside an a. This creates invalid HTML.

bonus_tips.tip: Use the browser DevTools inspector to see the element tree and verify your nesting is correct. Right-click any element and choose 'Inspect'.
When choosing between div and semantic elements, ask yourself: 'What does this represent?' If there's a specific answer (navigation, article, header), use the semantic element.
Data attributes can store JSON strings for complex data: data-config='{"theme": "dark", "lang": "en"}' then parse in JavaScript.
You can use CSS attribute selectors to style elements based on data attributes: [data-category='electronics'] { color: blue; }
The contenteditable attribute makes any element editable, even divs and spans. This is how rich text editors are built.
Multiple classes are separated by spaces in the class attribute, not commas: class='header primary-nav' not class='header, primary-nav'.
Use the hidden attribute instead of style='display: none' because it better communicates intent and works with accessibility tools.

subtopics.title: Global HTML Attributes
subtopics.description: Global attributes can be used on any HTML element regardless of type. They provide common functionality like identification (id), styling hooks (class), tooltips (title), and custom data storage (data-*). Understanding global attributes is essential for making elements interactive and maintainable.

when_to_use.point: Use id for unique elements that need to be targeted by CSS, JavaScript, or fragment links.
Use class for any element that needs styling or JavaScript selection, especially when multiple elements share the same styles.
Use title for adding helpful tooltips on buttons, abbreviations, and icons.
Use data-* attributes to store custom information that JavaScript will read.
Use hidden to hide content both visually and from screen readers.
Use lang when content is in a different language than the page default.

when_to_avoid.point: Never use the same id value twice on one page. IDs must be unique.
Avoid using style attribute for production styling. Use external CSS instead.
Don't rely on accesskey because different browsers and operating systems handle them differently.
Avoid contenteditable for complex editing. Build proper form inputs or use a rich text editor library.

mental_models.model: Think of id like a social security number. Each person (element) gets exactly one, and no two people can have the same number.
Think of class like job titles. Multiple people (elements) can have the same job title, and one person can have multiple roles.
Think of data attributes like pockets. They're places to store small bits of information you'll need later, but they don't affect what you see from the outside.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using duplicate id values. Each id must be unique per page. Use classes for multiple elements.
Adding spaces in id or data attribute names. Use hyphens or camelCase: id='user-profile' or data-user-id, not id='user profile'.
Forgetting that class attribute accepts multiple classes separated by spaces: class='btn primary' not class='btn, primary'.
Using presentational class names like 'red-text' instead of semantic names like 'error-message'.

bonus_tips.tip: You can use CSS to style based on attributes: [data-status='active'] { color: green; } targets elements with that data attribute value.
JavaScript can access data attributes via the dataset property: element.dataset.userId reads data-user-id.
The hidden attribute is better than style='display:none' because it communicates semantic intent to browsers and assistive technologies.

subtopics.title: Boolean HTML Attributes
subtopics.description: Boolean attributes are special attributes that represent true/false values by their presence or absence. If the attribute is present, it's true. If it's absent, it's false. No value is needed. These are commonly used on form inputs, buttons, and media elements.

examples.title: Form Input Boolean Attributes
examples.description: The most common boolean attributes used in forms to control input behavior and validation.
examples.code_snippet:
<!-- required: field must be filled before form submission -->
<input type="text" name="username" required>
<input type="email" name="email" required>

<!-- disabled: user cannot interact with this field -->
<input type="text" name="locked-field" value="Cannot edit" disabled>
<button disabled>Cannot Click</button>

<!-- readonly: user can see but not edit (value submits with form) -->
<input type="text" name="user-id" value="12345" readonly>

<!-- checked: checkbox or radio starts selected -->
<input type="checkbox" name="agree" checked> I agree to terms
<input type="radio" name="size" value="small" checked> Small
<input type="radio" name="size" value="large"> Large

<!-- autofocus: cursor starts in this field when page loads -->
<input type="text" name="search" autofocus placeholder="Search...">

<!-- multiple: allow multiple file selection or option selection -->
<input type="file" multiple>
<select multiple>
    <option>Option 1</option>
    <option>Option 2</option>
    <option>Option 3</option>
</select>
examples.output: Required fields must be filled before form submission. Disabled inputs are grayed out and cannot be changed. Readonly inputs show values but don't allow editing. Checked inputs start selected. Autofocus puts the cursor in the search box immediately. Multiple allows selecting several files or options.

examples.title: Correct vs Incorrect Boolean Attribute Syntax
examples.description: How to properly write boolean attributes. Remember: presence means true, absence means false.
examples.code_snippet:
<!-- âœ… CORRECT: Just the attribute name -->
<input type="checkbox" checked>
<input type="text" required>
<button disabled>Click</button>
<video autoplay muted></video>

<!-- âœ… ALSO CORRECT: Empty string value (HTML5 allows this) -->
<input type="checkbox" checked="">
<input type="text" required="">

<!-- âœ… ALSO CORRECT: Attribute name as value (XHTML style) -->
<input type="checkbox" checked="checked">
<input type="text" required="required">

<!-- âŒ WRONG: Using "true" or "false" as values -->
<input type="checkbox" checked="true">
<!-- This is still TRUE because attribute is present -->
<input type="checkbox" checked="false">
<!-- This is also TRUE! The attribute is present, value doesn't matter -->

<!-- âœ… CORRECT: To make it false, remove the attribute entirely -->
<input type="checkbox">
<!-- No checked attribute = not checked -->

<!-- âŒ WRONG: Setting boolean to "false" doesn't work -->
<button disabled="false">This is still disabled!</button>

<!-- âœ… CORRECT: Remove attribute to enable -->
<button>This works (no disabled attribute)</button>
examples.output: The correct examples all work identically. The checked attribute with any value (or no value) means checked. To uncheck it, remove the attribute entirely. You cannot set a boolean attribute to false using a value.

when_to_use.point: Use required on form inputs that must be filled before submission.
Use disabled to prevent interaction with form elements or buttons.
Use checked to pre-select checkboxes or radio buttons.
Use defer on script tags for better page load performance.
Use muted with autoplay on videos (most browsers require it).

when_to_avoid.point: Don't use autofocus on multiple elements. Only one element should have focus on page load.
Avoid autoplay on videos with sound. It's a poor user experience and browsers block it.
Don't use disabled when you mean readonly. Disabled values don't submit with forms, readonly values do.

mental_models.model: Think of boolean attributes like light switches. The switch is either on (attribute present) or off (attribute absent). There's no middle setting.

Boolean attributes are like flags on a mailbox. If the flag is up (attribute present), it means true. If the flag is down (attribute absent), it means false. The flag doesn't need a label saying 'this flag is up'.

common_mistakes.mistake: Trying to set boolean attributes to false using values like disabled='false'. This doesn't work. The attribute's presence makes it true. To make it false, remove the attribute entirely.
Confusing disabled and readonly. Disabled elements are grayed out and their values don't submit with forms. Readonly elements look normal and their values do submit.
Using autoplay on videos without muted. Most browsers block autoplay with sound for better user experience.
Adding multiple autofocus attributes. Only one element can have focus at page load.

bonus_tips.tip: In JavaScript, you can toggle boolean attributes: element.toggleAttribute('hidden') or element.disabled = true/false.
You can use CSS to style based on boolean attributes: input[disabled] { opacity: 0.5; } or input:required { border-color: red; }
The checked attribute sets initial state. User interaction changes the checked property in JavaScript, but the attribute stays the same.

subtopics.title: Custom Data Attributes
subtopics.description: Data attributes (data-*) allow you to store custom information on HTML elements that JavaScript can read and use. They're perfect for attaching metadata to elements without using non-standard attributes. Every data attribute starts with 'data-' followed by your custom name.

examples.title: Basic Data Attributes Usage
examples.description: How to create and use data attributes to store custom information on elements.
examples.code_snippet:
Wireless Mouse

$29.99

User: john_doe

Role: admin
examples.output: When the Buy Now button is clicked, JavaScript reads all the product information from data attributes. The user card stores user metadata that JavaScript can access. Notice how data-in-stock becomes dataset.inStock with camelCase.

examples.title: Naming Rules for Data Attributes
examples.description: How to properly name data attributes and how they convert to JavaScript property names.
examples.code_snippet:
<!-- Data attribute naming rules -->
<div 
    data-product-id="123"         â†’ dataset.productId
    data-price-usd="49.99"        â†’ dataset.priceUsd  
    data-in-stock="true"          â†’ dataset.inStock
    data-created-date="2024-01-01" â†’ dataset.createdDate
    data-user="john"              â†’ dataset.user
    data-x="10"                   â†’ dataset.x
>

<!-- âŒ WRONG: Don't use these characters -->
<div 
    data-price$="50"       <!-- $ not allowed -->
    data-user name="john"  <!-- spaces not allowed -->
    data-Price="50"        <!-- uppercase not recommended -->
>

<!-- âœ… CORRECT: Use hyphens for multi-word names -->
<div 
    data-product-category="electronics"
    data-user-email="user@example.com"
    data-last-updated="2024-01-15"
>

<script>
// Hyphenated names become camelCase in JavaScript
const element = document.querySelector('div');

// data-product-id â†’ dataset.productId
console.log(element.dataset.productId);

// data-price-usd â†’ dataset.priceUsd  
console.log(element.dataset.priceUsd);

// Setting data attributes from JavaScript
element.dataset.newAttribute = 'value'; // Creates data-new-attribute
element.dataset.userId = '456';         // Creates data-user-id
</script>
examples.output: Data attribute names in HTML use hyphens (data-product-id). In JavaScript, they become camelCase (dataset.productId). Names can only contain letters, numbers, hyphens, and must start with 'data-'.

examples.title: Storing Complex Data (JSON)
examples.description: You can store JSON strings in data attributes for more complex data structures.
examples.code_snippet: Widget Content
examples.output: Complex configuration can be stored as JSON strings in data attributes. JavaScript parses the JSON to access nested properties and arrays. This is useful for widget settings, chart configurations, and structured data.

when_to_use.point: Use data attributes to store custom information that JavaScript needs to access.
Use them when building interactive components like tabs, modals, or dropdowns that need to reference other elements.
Use them for configuration settings that control element behavior.
Use them for tracking and analytics metadata.
Use them to store identifiers that connect HTML elements to backend data.

when_to_avoid.point: Don't store sensitive information like passwords or API keys in data attributes. They're visible in HTML source code.
Don't use data attributes for data that should be in a database or backend. They're for client-side data only.
Avoid storing very large amounts of data in data attributes. They bloat HTML and hurt performance.
Don't use data attributes when a standard HTML attribute exists. Use href for links, src for images, etc.

mental_models.model: Think of data attributes like sticky notes on objects. They hold extra information that's not visible on the surface but that you can read when you need it.
Data attributes are like metadata in a photo file. The photo shows the image, but the metadata stores extra information (camera settings, date, location) that programs can read.

common_mistakes.mistake: Creating custom attributes without the data- prefix. Attributes like 'product-id' or 'user-name' are invalid HTML. Always use 'data-product-id' and 'data-user-name'.
Using spaces or special characters in data attribute names. Use hyphens for multi-word names: data-user-id not data-user_id or data-userId.
Storing sensitive information in data attributes. They're visible in the page source code and browser inspector.
Forgetting that data attribute values are always strings. If you store '123', you get the string '123' not the number 123. Convert with parseInt() or parseFloat() if needed.

bonus_tips.tip: You can style elements based on data attributes using CSS: [data-status='active'] { color: green; }
Access all data attributes at once: element.dataset returns an object with all data attributes.
You can add/remove data attributes dynamically: element.dataset.newAttr = 'value' or delete element.dataset.oldAttr
Data attributes are inherited by JavaScript frameworks like React, Vue, and Angular. They're framework-agnostic.
